C++: C++ is compiled directly to machine code which is then executed directly by the central processing unit.
Java: Java is compiled to byte-code which the Java virtual machine (JVM) then interprets at runtime. Actual Java implementations do just-in-time compilation to native machine code. Alternatively, the GNU Compiler for Java can compile directly to machine code.
final Foo a; // a declaration of a final" reference:

C++: // it is possible to modify the object
// but the reference will constantly point
// to the first object assigned to it"

Java: a = new Foo(); // Only in constructor

C++:
b = new Foo();
// ILLEGAL, it is not allowed to re-bind it
Java:
b = new Foo();
// ILLEGAL, it is not allowed to re-bind it

C++:
b->x = 5;
// LEGAL, the object can still be modified
Java:
b.x = 5;
// LEGAL, the object can still be modified
